titleStmt.title: Variants of Raising of a in stressed open syllable before a - CaCaC
titleStmt.author: Veronika Engler

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for Raising of a in stressed open syllable before a - CaCaC.

item.label: a > i sikat and a > u gumar
a > i sikat and a > a qamar
a > a and i become schwa for the Maghreb

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Elderly (70+), Old (60-70) and some middle age speakers show consistent raising of short medial a in stressed open syllable. The quality of the vowel seems to be sensitive to pharyngealization and labiality, thus, in environments combining labial and gutural consonants we find u: guṃar (moon), gufaṣ (cage). Raising is blocked in instances like saʕal (he asked), ṛagaṣ (he danced). In our data, so far, /h/, /ʕ/ and /x/ as C1 do not seem to systematically block the raising of a in CáCaC / CáCa patterns, while /ʔ/, /ḥ/, /ʕ/ as C2 do seem to systematically block the raising of a
Young speakers and some middle-aged speakers do not show raising of short medial a in stressed open syllable, unlike Elderly (70+), Old (60-70) and some middle age speakers who do show it.

Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:55 note that: “Raising of *a in *C1aC2aC3 to /i/ or /u/, C1 not being a back consonant such as /x/, /h/, /ḥ/, /ʕ/, /ġ/ is restricted to Bedouin dialects with the types *samak > símač, sabab > síbab, and bagar > búgar. The phenomenon is well-known in all Bedouin dialects of the peninsula and need not be discussed in detail here. It is absent in ruralite C, G and M dialects.”

Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:55 note that: “Raising of *a in *C1aC2aC3 to /i/ or /u/, C1 not being a back consonant such as /x/, /h/, /ḥ/, /ʕ/, /ġ/ is restricted to Bedouin dialects with the types *samak > símač, sabab > síbab, and bagar > búgar. The phenomenon is well-known in all Bedouin dialects of the peninsula and need not be discussed in detail here. It is absent in ruralite C, G and M dialects.”

Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:55 note that: “Raising of *a in *C1aC2aC3 to /i/ or /u/, C1 not being a back consonant such as /x/, /h/, /ḥ/, /ʕ/, /ġ/ is restricted to Bedouin dialects with the types *samak > símač, sabab > síbab, and bagar > búgar. The phenomenon is well-known in all Bedouin dialects of the peninsula and need not be discussed in detail here. It is absent in ruralite C, G and M dialects.”

The phenomenon is well-known in all Bedouin dialects of the peninsula and need not be discussed in detail here. It is absent in ruralite C, G and M dialects.”

The phenomenon is well-known in all Bedouin dialects of the peninsula and need not be discussed in detail here. It is absent in ruralite C, G and M dialects.”

The phenomenon is well-known in all Bedouin dialects of the peninsula and need not be discussed in detail here. It is absent in ruralite C, G and M dialects.”

Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:55 note that: “Raising of *a in *C1aC2aC3 to /i/ or /u/, C1 not being a back consonant such as /x/, /h/, /ḥ/, /ʕ/, /ġ/ is restricted to Bedouin dialects with the types *samak > símač, sabab > síbab, and bagar > búgar. The phenomenon is well-known in all Bedouin dialects of the peninsula and need not be discussed in detail here. It is absent in ruralite C, G and M dialects.”

The phenomenon is well-known in all Bedouin dialects of the peninsula and need not be discussed in detail here. It is absent in ruralite C, G and M dialects.”

Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:55 note that: “Raising of *a in *C1aC2aC3 to /i/ or /u/, C1 not being a back consonant such as /x/, /h/, /ḥ/, /ʕ/, /ġ/ is restricted to Bedouin dialects with the types *samak > símač, sabab > síbab, and bagar > búgar. The phenomenon is well-known in all Bedouin dialects of the peninsula and need not be discussed in detail here. It is absent in ruralite C, G and M dialects.”

Younes 2014:363 notes that in this case, the raising is blocked mainly when C1 is a guttural or when C2 is either l, r, or n, but with the exception of ḥ and ʕ, which seem to cause only partial raising to ə, while following labial consonants and the occurrence of m seem to render u instead of i: "En effet, pour ce schème, la règle implique que si C1 correspond à /ʾ/, /ʿ/, /h/, /ḥ/, /ġ/ ou /x/ ou alors si C2 correspond à /l/, /r/ ou /n/ même si dans ce dernier cas la distribution est aléatoire, l’élévation n’a pas lieu. Les pharyngales /ḥ/ et /ʿ/ pourraient avoir un traitement à part sur certains schèmes ce qui expliquerait les réalisations enregistrées. Pour ce qu’il en est de la laryngale /ʾ/, la coloration en /u/ de la voyelle est probablement le résultat de la bilabiale qui suit, en l’occurrence /m/".

'Except in definable phonetic contexts, i (ɪ, ə) occurs to the exclusion of a in open, non-final syllables. a occurs in open syllable (a) in the contiguity of the gutturals or where the following consonant is l, n, or r, when at the same time the vowel of the following syllable is a or ā.' (Johnstone 1967:27)

'Except in definable phonetic contexts, i (ɪ, ə) occurs to the exclusion of a in open, non-final syllables. a occurs in open syllable (a) in the contiguity of the gutturals or where the following consonant is l, n, or r, when at the same time the vowel of the following syllable is a or ā.' (Johnstone 1967:27)
'In the contiguity of the labials the vowel i, and also i>a, tends to become u.' (Johnstone 1967:28)
The Baḥārna dialect does not have the same restrictions on the raising of a as the ʕArab dialect.

'Except in definable phonetic contexts, i (ɪ, ə) occurs to the exclusion of a in open, non-final syllables. a occurs in open syllable (a) in the contiguity of the gutturals or where the following consonant is l, n, or r, when at the same time the vowel of the following syllable is a or ā.' (Johnstone 1967:27)

'Except in definable phonetic contexts, i (ɪ, ə) occurs to the exclusion of a in open, non-final syllables. a occurs in open syllable (a) in the contiguity of the gutturals or where the following consonant is l, n, or r, when at the same time the vowel of the following syllable is a or ā.' (Johnstone 1967:27)
'In the contiguity of the labials the vowel i, and also i>a, tends to become u.' (Johnstone 1967:28)
/G/ represents the IPA [G], the voiced uvular plosive.
CaCaC becomes CaCiC in non-emphatic/guttural environment: walid son
CaCaC becomes CaCiC in non-emphatic/guttural environment: walid son
